This is the preferred way of integrating Stripe Connect now, no matter which type of accounts you plan to use. The pair of API keys still exist for legacy reasons but should be ignored."

Then, you can use your Secret API key and also pass the Stripe-Account header set to the connected account‚Äôs ID. This lets Stripe know that your platform is making the request on behalf of that specific account.

Instead, as a platform you'll use your own API keys to make all requests. You'll use your publishable API key to tokenize payment methods and confirm payment intents. All tokenized payment methods live on the platform and can be used on your connected accounts automatically.
Starting w/ API v. 2019-02-19, creating a Custom acct does not return API keys anymore.

In March 2015, when Stripe launched Custom accounts the way authentication worked with Connect was also improved. The idea was that while platforms could get a pair of API keys per connected account, they didn't need those anymore and could directly use the acct ID.
For those reasons (and likely others), the same API keys aren't reused. This means that a platform had its own keys and then it also had a pair of keys for each of their connected accounts.

This is expected. If the keys were the same:

1. The connected acct could roll their keys and break their integration with the platform
2. The acct wouldn‚Äôt be able to revoke access for a specific plat
3. Stripe wouldn‚Äôt know if a request came from the acct or the plat

How Connect was 1st built -- not current state:

When an account connected to a platform, the plat received the acct's ID with a pair of API keys. Those keys are specific to that acct + platform. They are different from what's in the acct‚Äôs dashboard or in the platform dash.

When you use the API to create an object like a Customer or a Checkout Session, you use one of your API keys that you see in the dashboard. The API key is what tells Stripe that a specific user is making a req so that Stripe knows to which acct to create the object on.

How do API keys work with Stripe Connect? The short story is: the combo of your platform API keys with the ID of the connected account is how you authenticate requests for the connected acct. (Not by passing the API keys of the connected account, anymore). üßµ for the long story!

.@_ttmarek reminded me of another one! 

By default Firebase will parse the request body so you need to use `requests.rawBody.toString()` when verifying the signatures: https://t.co/3DFsumubiF.

The signature is not in the request headers. In an older implementation, signatures weren't included in the request headers unless the endpoint's secret was revealed in the dashboard. Now, Stripe sends the signature headers for all event notifications.  

</üßµ> https://t.co/nMpEELp8cU

Handling webhooks with #AWS Lambda? You might need some custom logic to access the raw request body. 

In API Gateway, set up a Body Mapping Template with Content-Type: application/json (just this ‚Äì don't include `; charset=utf-8` afterwards):

https://t.co/WGzZrMzMgf.
Using ASCII sometimes trips up folks working in PHP. Additionally, when working with stripe-python you'll likely want to decode as utf-8: https://t.co/fGagQv4SNe.

The webhook handler's string encoding for the payload is not set to UTF-8. The Stripe API treats all strings as UTF-8. The signature header is calculated from a UTF-8 encoded string on the Stripe side. Enforce UTF-8 for that payload in your webhook handler.

Depending on the node framework, a workaround in this GitHub issue might also be helpful: https://t.co/GW3pofFj6K.

For instance, stripe-node with bodyParser override: https://t.co/f78zvByKgv.

For signatures to match, the webhook handler must use the exact same string as Stripe. Ensure you're working with the HTTP request's raw body without any interference by the framework or any libraries.

The payload in the webhook handler is different from the data Stripe signed. Often, the web framework or a library tried to be helpful in middleware and may have:
* parsed the body as JSON
* changed order of properties
* modified indentation

--- 

*cough* bodyParser *cough* ü•¥

If you are using Stripe Connect, you'll likely have at least two webhook endpoints, one for your account's events and one for connected accounts' events. Each has a different signing secret, and the webhook handler might only be using one. https://t.co/Ev4tkQRSW5

The webhook signing secret used in the webhook handling code is not the same as shown in your Stripe dashboard for that webhook endpoint.  Each webhook endpoint configured in the dashboard or for the Stripe CLI has a unique signing secret. A sig looks ~like: `whsec_xyz123`.

Some context... When @StripeDev sends webhook event notifications, the POST req headers include a signature to prove the event came from Stripe. You can automatically verify sigs to trust the event's content vs. retrieving it through the API. Docs: https://t.co/xQRPrgq2ys.

<üßµ>

You pay a fixed amount, let's call it $5 to sell something. The post includes a neutral location, buyers bid, buyers pick an appointment slot, you get a text telling you when they will arrive at the "exchange point" and you go deliver the goods. No need to haggle, $'s in the bank

Definitely feels like I need some mashup of ebay + craigslist which includes a bidding and pre-payment system before delivery, even for local stuff. And a way to schedule appointments a la @Calendly (maybe an integration?)

You post the thing
then have to coordinate appointment times
then some people are no-shows
then other people might be driving a far distance to an appointment right after the person who just purchased the thing
everyone wants to haggle on price

I'm frustrated by the experience of selling a physical goods on craigslist / fb market place. Specifically the part where you have multiple buyers interested and it's not clear what to tell them about one-another. Like someone asks "is it still available" yeah but not for long?

In @headfirstgo the "pill container" analogy is used for an Array, which I really love. It's fixed size, and you index into the collection with a day of the week (0-6).

It can't grow.

Much better than the ladder analogy ;)

In CS101 cerca 2005, I remember:

program is a recipe
variable is a box
array is a ladder
function is a "paragraph in a recipe"
hash map is a phone book (this made ~more sense in '05?)
OOP uses the vehicle analogy (move_forward, self.speed)

It's super interesting to see which analogies books and online learning platforms like code academy and https://t.co/R88Ctfn6Z9 use to teach simple concepts like variables and arrays. 

In my experience analogies are the most powerful teaching tool. What're some of your faves?
